title: Mobility groups and their needs in the future

author: Kati Kiiskilä, Finnra - Finnish Road Administration

segmentation: Dear colleagues, good afternoon.
So I will present you the results of a small study that is financed by and by the finish Rd administration not actually done in the Finish Rd administration.
Actually, I myself I'm not a researcher but my colleague Patrick is killer she is.
But this research was conducted by a consultant group.
Um?
Let me check.
Technology.
OK so I will start by presenting some background for this small study.
I'd like to say that the trend that we are witnessing in people's lifestyles and attitudes.
At least in the in the industrialized world that this individualization, as a sociologist, I just have to say that because all the sociologist are telling you that all the time.
Which causes changes in people's everyday life patterns and an.
Animal behavior also travel behavior, becoming more and more diverse and then less predictable also.
Then at the same time, well as most of us, probably no transport planning in Europe is shifting away from the so called era of predict and provide.
The new era of transport policy has been described.
Of the air of wealth, mobility, management or or demand management.
Are important.
Focus is the effect peoples travel behavior.
And what follows from these two?
Separate trends, I would say that there is a deeper understanding of different, even conflicting mobility needs of various population groups and people.
And I would like to emphasize the word to understand these needs, not only predict.
And what that mean?
By understanding I mean that well.
First of all, I think we we need also quality that they were not only quoted, that they were research on travel needs.
And Secondly, I think we need to divide the the kind of a uniform concept of a user or customer or traveler or citizen.
A more diverse understanding of different groups.
One way to answer this this need of and understanding is, well, a method that is borrowed from marketing research, user segmentation or consumer segmentation.
This has been done by in the road sector, for example in by different Rd authorities in some countries or by municipalities.

In order to gain understanding of the of the most important factors that motivate people's or different user groups, travel behavior or for example in some cities, for example in Copenhagen, I noticed they have they have tried to find out the user groups in order to identify different public transport transport users.
And also the segmentation can be an aid in impact analysis, for example when conducting environmental impact analysis.
When trying to understand the impacts of a certain transport policy Measure 2.
On different groups.
A Rd engineer told me this.
This picture reminds reminded him of a traffic modeling which I personally don't know much about but but anyway, on the left side.
I listed some factors that affect a persons mobility behavior or populations mobility behavior as we, as you probably all know.
For example, demographical factors, age of family size, such things, then people employment or income.

Then the land to use in the area, people's lifestyle of their consuming patterns, their personal values and attitudes, and then the supply of different transport modes or car ownership and such things.
And then what what becomes out of this is on the right side.
Then this mobility patterns how a person moves for what trip purposes, how often, how much.
And then also persons preferences or values what they value in their travel?
Do they value Accessibility or travel time or or more?
Do they value more flexibility or environmental issues?
So such things?
And why I'm presenting this picture here is that this user segmentation can be done and has been done on on both this.
Groups affect us either on this on the left side, the qualities of the users, or those on the right side of the behavior of the users.
This has also been done in marketing for other purposes, then then, then transportation.
That was the background, but so to go to our research project.
It was called personal mobility needs and this is.
This is a rather small scale project in comparison with some other studies that have been presented here in in other sessions, the Big European Union research projects.
So this was only financed by us finished road and ministration for our purposes.
The aim of this study was to identify different.
User segments or or traveler, traveler traveler groups and describe the travel needs and how we did this is that we use the data of the Finnish National Travel Survey.
In some countries this is called passenger Traffic Survey, but so this is I guess done in most of the countries.

This this National Travel Survey and in fact you can find by the way you can find information on our travel survey on that web page that you see there, but we used the data of that survey in this in this research.
So two to go on what what we did, what was done.
In this study, five mobility groups or segments were formed according to the use of time by the travelers.
First of all, it was assumed.
The.
Not very surprising assumption that people's everyday life can can roughly be divided into 3 family time or well.
Also, you can call that community time work related time and leisure.
And then it was assumed.
And we also found out that in various stages or along a person's life.
A different amount of time is spent for this three so called anchors of your daily life.
And also that the well, as these anchors affect your daily life and they bind your time use and your everyday mobility.
It's it's mostly these two family and work that that bind you bind your time and then if those are not present then you have more more time for them.
For the Ledger.
So this was behind them.
The grouping and what came out of it was these also maybe not so surprising groups, but still.
We we divided the the actually the finished finished population into these five groups.
Well, children and teenagers.
Then the family bound people then Thirdly the family and work bound people.
Then fourthly, the work bound people, and then the last, the so-called independent.
In in this context.
And yeah, how?
Because we were using statistical data.
We of course needed to define this.
What do we mean by this family and work anchor?
So by we defined the person who's working or studying part time or full time they were defined to have this work.
Anchor and then persons who had children less than 13.
Yeah, sold in their family.
They were defined to have this this family bind and then after after this analysis of the travel habits or mobility habits of these groups was done.
Based on the data by the National Travel Survey and what we did find out was that they actually did differ quite significantly from each other.
These groups, in relation to their travel, but patterns, mobility patterns daily and then partly also in relation to their needs and values.
So what we we did find use user segmentation that we were looking for.
Then I'll just show you some data data on these groups.
Well, yeah, we can see just the description of the groups in the finished population.
The share of these groups in different age groups.
Well, quite understandably.
For example, the the red color, meaning the family and work bound people.
Well, those people you can find in mostly in age groups from let's say 3250, which is quite understandable.
Well, for example, the green color that means the so called independent.
They were of course mostly elderly people, retired people, but the but there was also some of them in other.
Other age groups too.
But this is this is some background data.
And then as soon as I mentioned the mobility patterns of the groups, they were studied extensively.
And their trip purpose is varied and the trip rate and the distance traveled.
Yeah, we see.
Well, here we see the the trip purposes and then the total mileage per day or total distance traveled per day of these five groups.
Just to mention, yeah how we defined those three.
Trip purpose is there.
The work related trips well they were included work, work, travel than other work related travel.
Then going to school, going to daycare, then the family related trips that was defined to.
Contain grocery shopping, other personal business, and then also chauffeuring your family members and then the third, third category.
Leisure related trips that was, well that included Holidays and visiting friends and then other shopping than the daily grocery shopping and then other leisure.
So here we see some.
Some background figures IMAX.
Really not going into detail into them, I'm showing you 2 pictures that I that that were.
I guess I would say one of the most interesting results of this study here we see.
The share of the departure time of trips in a day of these five groups, I hope you do see those.
Those colors.
So what we found out there was that the daily activity patterns of these five groups they differ quite quite remarkably on week days as we see here in this picture.
But they were quite similar weekends when well, when you don't go to work or don't go to school.
But still this it is quite interesting to see this.
This difference, so this is the actually the same picture on weekends and we can see that that people.
When people travel, it's it's quite similar in all the groups during week.
Then what was also done actually after the actual study.
The size of these five mobility groups in Finland and the amount of trips they make was forecasted for the following 35 years.
But actually in this study, mainly demographical factors were taken into account.
So meaning the size of this population groups.
We didn't.
We didn't take into account the account behavior of the of the groups well, and in reality this situation is of course more complex, But anyway.
The basis of this.

Forecasting well the amount of the so-called independent people grows fastest, which of course tells us about the the amount of elderly population in the future in Finland and also in in other European countries is growing.
And then maybe I'll show it here.
What we noticed is that.
That the amount of leisure related trips.
Well, it will grow a little bit until the 2025, but it will start going down diminishing until the year 2040.
But when you look at the line of family trips, the amount of them will grow and will still keep growing.
Until the year 2040.
So to conclude.
Um?
So we use this date of this Finnish national Travel Survey to to make this user segmentation and well, actually the the purpose of this was was.
Do to find out the different groups whose behavior we can would help us understand, understand our Rd users more deeply and that that is something we accomplished in the study.
And so, well, if the same kind of data is available in other countries, this national Travel Survey data.
This similar analysis could be made in other countries too, which would make it possible to compare.
These results internationally.
Um?
And then I would like to find out some consequences for.
For road and transport planning, I would like to say that this user segmentation it is a useful tool when you want to access users verifying needs more deeply.
What we also need is quality that there is a interview.
Studies on the needs of these groups.
So I'm not saying that this quantitative data is enough, but it was.
It was a good start.
And then then I would like to emphasize the growing amount of family related to travel, especially caused by the need to care for elderly parents.
So in this study we only due to the date that we had.
We only could take into account.
No need to refer your children, but but they need to take care of your elderly parents.
This will be a significant significant trend in the future.
An what requirements this?
This sets for our transport policy.
I think this would be an important research topic in the future.
Thanks for your attention.
If you any questions.
